section.name: Differences from RFC 8984
section.t: This section documents all significant differences from RFC 8984. Insignificant differences, such as formatting, grammar or typos are not documented.

section.name: Applied Errata
section.t: All verified errata of RFC 8984 was applied to this document:

section.name: Obsolete Properties
section.t: The following properties became obsolete:

dd.t: This is incompatible with iCalendar, which deprecated the EXRULE property in .
See .
This is incompatible with the following definitions of the iCalendar RRULE property:

ul.li: The RRULE property SHOULD NOT be specified more than once.
The recurrence set generated with multiple RRULE properties is undefined.

dd.t: The newly defined single-valued recurrenceRule property replaces it.
See .
This property was obsoleted for the following reasons:

ul.li: Custom time zones in calendaring data increase implementation complexity, introduce inefficiencies and are error-prone, as described for CalDAV and iCalendar in .
In practice, the only non-IANA time zone identifiers are Microsoft time zone names. These can be converted to IANA time zones, e.g. using the International Components for Unicode software library.
The property contradicts the stated goal of JSCalendar to avoid ambiguities and pitfalls of iCalendar, defined in .

dd.t: See .
This property was obsoleted for the following reasons:

ul.li: It only is relevant for rich-text descriptions, but the related iCalendar STYLED-DESCRIPTION property does not support referring to attached media.
It only is applicable for Link objects having a "data:" URI as href property value. But even the definition of the Link object recommends not to use "data:" URIs as values in the href property.
A Link with "data:" URI converts to an iCalendar BINARY value. But these are marginally supported by CalDAV clients, which tend to prefer using WebDAV managed attachments .

dd.t: See .
These got replaced with the newly defined Event.endTimeZone property:

ul.li: They were meant to be equivalent to the iCalendar DTEND property. But the semantics were undefined if multiple Location objects had "relativeTo=end" and the "timeZone" property set.
Their semantics were undefined for Task objects.
They were incompatible with the iCalendar VLOCATION component, which neither defines how to set a time zone identifier or how the VLOCATION relates to start and end.

dd.t: See .
This is incompatible with the iCalendar PARTICIPANT component:

ul.li: The PARTICIPANT component may contain multiple VLOCATION components and LOCATION properties.
The PARTICIPANT component does not support referring to other VLOCATION components or LOCATION properties

dd.t: The description of the Event object type in reflects this:

ul.li: It stated: "Multiple participants may partake in the event at multiple locations."
It now states: "Multiple participants may partake in the event."

dd.t: See .
No equivalent element exists in iCalendar and its current single-valued definition is likely to conflict with any related future extension of the PARTICIPANT component.
See .
This became obsolete for the following reasons:

ul.li: It is incompatible with the newly introduced iCalendar VSTATUS component, which may occur multiple times in the PARTICIPANT and VTODO components.
The VSTATUS component introduces new semantics to a task's progress and status, which better be defined by a future JSCalendar extension for tasks.

dd.t: See and .
All properties defined solely for the TimeZone and TimeZoneRule object types became obsolete, because the "timeZones" property became obsolete.
See .

section.name: JMAP for Calendars
section.t: The following common use properties became reserved for JMAP for Calendars:

dd.t: No equivalent element exists in iCalendar and no consensus for default alarms in CalDAV and iCalendar was found at IETF as part of .
See .
This requires further work by IETF to update iTIP with the PARTICIPANT component and JSCalendar. This property may later be redefined for common use.
See .
This requires further work by IETF to update iTIP with the PARTICIPANT component and JSCalendar. This property may later be redefined for common use.

section.name: Scheduling Extensions for CalDAV and iTIP
section.t: The following common use properties became reserved for future JSCalendar extensions of Scheduling Extensions for CalDAV and iTIP:

See .
This mainly is applicable in scheduling over CalDAV.
See .

No equivalent element exists in iCalendar and this property mainly is relevant in context of a combined calendaring and mail service. Note that the Participant.sentBy property does not become reserved: it is equivalent to the iCalendar SENT-BY parameter.
See .
This requires further work by IETF. Specifically, the iTIP definitions of the REPLY method and how to forward invitation requests () must be updated.
See .
This requires further work by IETF to update iTIP with the PARTICIPANT component or JSCalendar. This property may later be redefined for common use.
See .
This only is applicable in scheduling over CalDAV.

See .
This only is applicable in scheduling over CalDAV.
See .
This requires further work by IETF. For compatibility with iCalendar, the newly introduced Participant.calendarAddress property replaces it.
See .

section.name: Localization Extensions for iCalendar and JSCalendar
section.t: The following properties became reserved for future JSCalendar and iCalendar extensions for multi-lingual calendar data:

dd.t: This requires further work by IETF. The "localizations" property primarily was introduced in JSCalendar for event publishing, but neither the Event Publishing extensions for iCalendar nor other iCalendar extensions define how to localize iCalendar data. This property may later be redefined for common use.
See .

section.name: Reserved for Future RFCs
section.t: The following properties became reserved for some future JSCalendar extension RFCs:

dd.t: This requires further work by IETF. The VirtualLocation "description" property does not convert to any parameter of the CONFERENCE property. It would require to define a new parameter or to introduce a new component to augment the CONFERENCE property with a DESCRIPTION or STYLED-DESCRIPTION property. For consistency, the Location "description" property became reserved, too.
See and .

section.name: Reserved for Internal Use
section.t: The following properties became reserved for internal use by JSCalendar:

dd.t: This property name already was defined for internal use only in the recurrenceOverrides property, but registering it for common use had made it appear as being a regular property. Making this a reserved property is to help clarify its purpose. has been updated accordingly.
See .

section.name: Updated Properties
section.t: The following property definitions were updated:

dd.t: The original definition required this property be set on every object type. The type and property notation in now matches the one in JSContact, and the @type property is optional in the majority of cases.

The original definition instructed to set the "parent" relation on a snooze alert. It now instructs to set the newly defined "snooze" relation, for compatibility with the VALARM "SNOOZE" relationship type (.
The original definition did not define that the map keys represent keys of Alert objects in the "alerts" property.
See .
JSCalendar now supports default types for properties of type A|B. The default type of this property now is OffsetTrigger.
See .
The original definition only allowed one purpose to be set, which is incompatible with the multi-valued iCalendar DISPLAY parameter. It now supports setting multiple purposes.
Setting this property does not anymore require the "rel" property of the Link object be set to "icon".
See .
The original definition restricted the value of this property to registered link types. It now also allows extension relation types for compatibility with the LINKREL parameter.
See .

The original definitions required their values to identify Participant objects. This was incompatible with iCalendar when the DELEGATED-TO, DELEGATED-FROM or MEMBER parameters contained a calendar address but no ATTENDEE property with that same calendar address. The new definition now requires the property values to be calendar addresses.
Also, they now require the calendarAddress property to be set.
See .

dl.dt: Participant.expectReply, Participant.invitedBy, Participant.kind, Participant.participationStatus, Participant.progress, Participant.sentBy:

dd.t: The original definitions were incompatible with iCalendar: they did not require the (now reserved) sendTo property to be set, but their equivalent iCalendar parameters require an ATTENDEE property. They now require the calendarAddress property to be set.
See .
The original definition was incompatible with iCalendar:

ul.li: It did not cover the "REQ-PARTICIPANT" value of the ROLE parameter. It now defines the new "required" role.

The "roles" property is multi-valued but the ROLE parameter is single-valued and only allowed to be set once on an ATTENDEE. For compatibility, a precendence of Participant roles got defined for converting roles to iCalendar.

It was mandatory for a Participant, but the (now reserved) sendTo property was not. This was incompatible with iCalendar, which required an ATTENDEE property to set the ROLE parameter. It now is optional, but requires the calendarAddress property to be set.

It defined a "contact" role, but this role later got redefined as an enumerated value of the PARTICIPANT-TYPE property. It now removed this role and leaves defining participant types to a future JSCalendar extension.

dd.t: See .

The original definition specified the empty relation to represent an unspecified relationship. It now defines the empty relation to default to "parent", unless overridden, for compatibility with the RELATED-TO property.
See .

The original definition defined these as optional, but this is incompatible with iCalendar: if the Task object's timeZone property is set, then it requires the DUE property or DTSTART property be set in the VTODO component. It now requires at least one of the "due" or "start" properties be set, if the "timeZone" property is set.

The original definition did not require the "start" property be set if the "recurrenceRule" property is set. But this is incompatible with the RRULE property, which requires the DTSTART property be set in the VTODO component. The "start" property now is required if the "recurrenceRule" or "recurrenceId" properties are set.
The "showWithoutTime" property having value "true" now requires at least one of the "due" or "start" properties be set.
See .

section.name: New Properties
section.t: The following new properties were defined:

dd.t: This got introduced for better interoperatibility with iCalendar, where the VEVENT and VTODO components allow at most one LOCATION property to be present. While VLOCATION components may occur multiple times, implementations need to know which Location to choose for the LOCATION property.
See .
This replaces the reserved replyTo property.
See .
This replaces the obsoleted recurrenceRules property.
See .
This replaces the obsoleted Location.relativeTo and Location.timeZone properties.
See .
This is for compatibility with the iCalendar STYLED-DESCRIPTION property of the VLOCATION component.
See .
This replaces the reserved Participant.sendTo property.
See .
This is for compatibility with the iCalendar STYLED-DESCRIPTION property of the PARTICIPANT component.
See .
This is for consistency with the definition of the Location object type. The newly defined VCONFERENCE component will be allowed to contain the STYLED-DESCRIPTION property.
See .

section.t: The following type definitions became obsolete:

dd.t: The "timeZones" property became obsolete.

section.name: Updated Types
section.t: The following type definitions were updated:

dd.t: The original definitions supported fractional seconds. This is incompatible with the iCalendar DATE-TIME and DURATION types defined in and .
